descriptions:
The response does not accomplish the task set by part A of the question.

Part A: Describe one reason African American artists documented their subjects during the nineteenth and early twentieth centuries as demonstrated by the image of the Garveyite family.

Examples that earn this point include but are not limited to the following:

  • During the New Negro movement, African American photographers sought to portray Black people as progressive and forward-looking.

  • James Van Der Zee’s photographs depict well-dressed African Americans in settings of prosperity and show new possibilities for Black people.

  • African American photographers of the New Negro era wanted to highlight images that reflected agency and progress, themes that were central to the movement.

  • During the New Negro movement, African Americans artists documented their subjects and settings to challenge racial stereotypes.

  • African American artists produced images such as the Garveyite Family to exhibit pride, to show the beauty of Black life, and to demonstrate the achievements of African Americans.

  • Photographers during the New Negro movement sought to create a distinctive Black aesthetic, one which depicted and celebrated African Americans in the context of their own lives.

The response accomplishes the task set by part A of the question.

title: Part B

Select a point value to view scoring criteria and examples or to score the response.

Each criterion is achieved independently.
descriptions:
The response does not accomplish the task set by part B of the question.

Part B: Describe one specific example of an African American contribution to an artistic field, other than photography, during the nineteenth or twentieth century.

Examples that earn this point include but are not limited to the following:

  • Enslaved and free African Americans incorporated performative elements from Africa into Christian hymns, leading to the creation of gospel music and blues music.

  • African Americans incorporated African aesthetic influences as they established quilt-making as a tradition and a medium of storytelling and memory keeping.

  • The Fisk Jubilee Singers helped to introduce the tradition of African American spirituals to an international audience in the early twentieth century.

  • The Harlem Renaissance represented a wealth of Black literary, artistic, and musical achievements, including poetry, painting, and jazz.

  • The 1930s and 1940s saw a proliferation of African American blues and jazz musicians who built upon earlier musical traditions that were influenced by a wide range of Black experiences.

  • The development of hip-hop culture grew out of New York City in the 1970s to become an international movement, which included rap and breakdancing.

The response accomplishes the task set by part B of the question.

title: Part C
stimulusHtml:
Select a point value to view scoring criteria and examples or to score the response.

Each criterion is achieved independently.
descriptions:
The response does not accomplish the task set by part C of the question.

Part C: Using a different specific example than used in part B, explain how African Americans used visual media or other artistic fields to advocate for social change in the mid-to-late twentieth century.

Examples that earn this point include but are not limited to the following:

  • During the Civil Rights movement, protests and police brutality, especially in the South, were televised and documented. Photographs of brutality, such as the image of Emmett Till, helped to raise national awareness about the problem of racial discrimination and the need for change.

  • The Black Arts Movement of the 1960s and 1970s used art to help achieve Black liberation and connected contemporary artists with those who had come before them.

  • Hip-hop culture combined elements of Black fashion, jazz, and poetry to help put a voice to the ongoing political, economic, and social challenges faced by African Americans.

  • Graffiti art became a vital form of artistic expression and was a part of hip-hop culture that projected the voices, perspectives, and creativity of marginalized inner-city youth of color. Graffiti became a platform for urban youth to bring attention to political issues and struggles.

  • African American images in film and television became more realistic and complex, helping to debunk negative stereotypes of Black families. Although entertaining, sitcoms like The Jeffersons, Good Times, and The Fresh Prince of Bel Air brought attention to serious social and political issues while creating roles for African American actors and opportunities for Black writers and directors.

  • African Americans wrote plays examining race relations in the United States. For example, August Wilson wrote Fences, a play that explores racism, hardships, and the complex realities that African American families face.

The response accomplishes the task set by part C of the question.
